Be sad, as we would make ye think ye see The very persons of our noble story As they were living; think you see them great, Then in a moment, see, How soon this mightiness meets misery: And, if you can be merry then, I'll say, A man may weep upon his wedding- day. Card: During Act 1 Scene 4 a misjudged stage effect began fire.  All Is True - Shooting Script 2. The map. Fire flicks viciously through the drawn image of Globe Theatre. CUT.
An explosive crack of fire . A figure stands silhouetted against the frame-filling flames. Shouts and screams and panic off screen.

Low wide shot of a grey, smoking, empty wasteland. A figu stands in the smoldering aftermath of the fire. Close on the figure, who slowly turns to face us. Not the Shakespeare of the famous portrait, but simply the man. A haunted man. CARD. The Globe Theatre burned entirely to the ground. CARD. William Shakespeare never wrote another play.

text: INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - EVENING 6 Shakespeare’s family, Anne, Susanna, and Judith sit toget
He writes the life of a King? And calls it All is True? Your father has some nerve. Susanna defensive of her father.
No doubt the specific events will be true. And the people involved. The rest is anybody’s guess. It might be true.
Nothing is ever true.
The word of God is true. Judith raises a contemptuous eyebrow.  10 All Is True - Shooting Script 3.
Noise. Flaming torches. A group of righteous Puritans are protesting outside the tavern. Amongst their leaders is D John Hall (Susanna’s husband).

Be not deceived! Neither drunkards, nor fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, shall inherit the kingdom of God. A messenger rushes up to a puritan who glances at the mes and then shares it with John Hall. Hall Knows he must lea
A thump of hooves. A horse gallops across the wide lowlan of the garden of England.

location: THE COURT YARD OF A COUNTRY TAVERN

text: An exhausted Will sits in the partially covered booth of Inn. A frail boy (11) watches him. Will barely notices th child. The boy wears a ragged cloak against the chill, hi face partly hid. The boy sees that Will’s cloak is burned
We heard a theatre burned Sir? Which one was it?
Mine. Will has scarcely glanced at him.. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 10 John Hall has brought news. The family are shocked.
A fire?
A furnace. We must prepare ourselves for the worst. It is in God’s hands.
Well don’t sound so bloody pleased about it.  11 All Is True - Shooting Script 4.
Will nurses a mug of ale. Eyes far away. Deep in thought. landlady brings bread and cheese. A Romany. Hard bitten b with good reason. Will’s attention is far away.
Don’t see a lot of strangers. (beat) Name’s Dotia. It’s my pub. Will ignores her. The Landlady becomes wary.
And who might you be?
(startled) Who am I? He looks away again. Almost to himself?
Who am I? (far away) I... I have worked in the theatre. This exchange has confirmed her suspicions.
Right then. I’1l have the reckoning before you eat if it’s all the same to you. A look from Will.
I seen you strolling player types before.
And?
An’ you ain’t exactly gen’lemen.

I am exactly a gentleman and Non sanz droict. (the landlady doesn’t understand) “Not without right”. You might see it on my Coat of Arms. He reaches into his bag and pulls out a heavy bag of coin He tosses a gold coin down. The landlady’s eyes widen.  12 All Is True - Shooting Script 5.
Gentleman enough for you?

location: THE COURT YARD OF A COUNTRY TAVERN

text: Will preoccupied still. About to leave. The Boy is there, ignored by Will.
You're Shakespeare. The poet. You tell stories.
I used to.
I had a story. But it was never finished. Will is fastening his cloak against the chill. Irritated this nonsense.
Will you finish it for me? Please? Will is becoming impatient for his horse. Looks to the ta door.
I’m done with stories lad. And I wouldn't know how to finish yours.

Yes you would. Of course you would. Light thickens in the silent dusk. Will ignores the child stares at the road ahead, as he waits, fearful, wondering After a moment, he looks back around. The boy has gone. T Landlady comes to the door.
Where’s the Boy?
What Boy?
The lad who took my horse?

No boy here. We found your horse untethered. Will shivers. He looks out at the gloomy light. He looks back at the Landlady who clearly has seen and he nothing.  13 14 15 16 17 All Is True - Shooting Script 6.
Moving closer across the map of the town, which now featu the famous Clopton Bridge.

The Puritans still protest the tavern. Will walks past. The tavern protest continues. A man emerges from the Tave John Lane, a surly drunkard. He glances furiously at the Puritans and spits on the ground. They stare menacingly b

Will outside his house. He pauses at the front door to lo at the Coat of Arms that hangs above it. He seems to take strength from this. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - NIGHT 16 Will has returned and at table with the family. Will is silent, shaken. It is uneasy reunion.
I rejoice to see you safe Father in Law. We all do.
I thank you for it John.

God burned your theatre but spared you. Thus is he both wise and merciful. Perhaps this is offered as comfort but it doesn’t give an Will looks at John for a moment then stares once more int the fire. Remembering. Thinking. Anne breaks the silence.
And when Will you return to London? Will looks at her blankly. The significance of this sinks slowly in for his family.
The upstairs windows lit by candle.  18 19 20 21 All Is True - Shooting Script 7. INT. HALL’S CROFT BEDCHAMBER- NIGHT 18 Susanna and John Hall.
I always thought he’d end his life in London. Its where he lived.
It doesn’t matter where he lived, or where he dies, all that matters is who will be his heir.
I am his heir. And our daughter Elizabeth after me.
Not if your sister gives hima grandson.
Or we do. There is coldness and disappointment as they meet each other’s eye.
Candles at two separate windows upstairs. INT. JUDITH’S BED CHAMBER - NIGHT 20 Judith lies alone, her face is blank. But there are tears her cheeks. She seems to cry without emotion. Damaged.
Anne is in the room. Will at the door.
Good night Husband. Anne begins to close the door on him.
Twenty years Will. We’ve seen you less and less. Will accepts the admonishment in silence.
To us you are a guest. And a guest must have the best bed. Rest well.  22 23 24 All Is True - Shooting Script 8. Will is saddened but can only retreat.
A contemplative Will takes in the familiar countryside as walks. Children are playing. He takes pleasure in their play. Two young women approach.
Mr. Shakespeare? Is it true what they say? That you are he? The great poet?
Poet certainly.
Such an honour. Still traumatized, he takes pleasure at this attention. I in stark contrast to his reception at home.

Will is walking along the once familiar street. He feels a stranger but one who has earned his right to be there. wears fine clothes and takes pride that people greet him. a figure of respect. “Mr. Shakespeare.” “An honour sir” “ heard you had come to live amongst us once more, such excitement”.

Will stands by a name plaque outside Stratford Grammar. H mind is filled with memories. He listens at a window. He hears a class of teenage boys being instructed by their teacher. He hears a stern voice call out “William Shakespeare!” It was just a memory. The voice that called Will was the current master come out to greet him.
Mr. Shakespeare isn’t it? I saw you looking in. Please, perhaps a few words of inspiration for the boys?
I... forgive me.. I think not. Will turns away but then he turns back.  25 26 27 All Is True - Shooting Script
Tell them... Tell them to get money.
Money sir?
Money. Money and property.
No words of wisdom? Philosophy? Food for the soul? Will considers this for a moment.
Money.
INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING
I thought perhaps, I would make a garden.
We've got a garden.
Not a kitchen Garden. Or a flower garden. But a special one. For Hamnet.
Hamnet’s in Paradise. He doesn’t need a garden.
Perhaps I do. Anne shrugs as if to say “do as you please”.

Through the windows we see the Hall family at 25 The second best house in the town sits quietly in the 26 Dinner. Anne, Judith and Will. They eat in silence for so time. Eventually Will breaks it. 27 supper.  28 29 30 All Is True - Shooting Script 10. INT. HALL’S CROFT - NIGHT 28 Susanna, John and Elizabeth Hall. Also in silence. Susann throws a discreet smile at little Elizabeth to momentaril break the grimness.
Your father’s mind is on his legacy.
Your mind is on his legacy. John does not like her tone.
And therefore must be yours. For I am your husband and what concerns me concerns you. John Hall gives Susanna a long and significant look.
Will, like a stranger in a strange land, walks through th existing plants and flowers, scouting for his new plan. H very engaged.
Will digging. Enjoying the air. The buzzing insects. The little birds that try to steal his seeds. Anne brings him water. Will leans upon his spade, puffed
Digging up roots. Heavy work.
You'll find that. Will drinks long and deep. A thought amuses him.
I once uprooted an entire Wood and moved it across a stage to Dunsinane.
Bit different in the real world. A beat as their familiar akwardness settles.
He showed such promise Anne.  31 32 All Is True - Shooting Script 11.
You scarcely knew him.
I knew him. Through his poems.
You say poems.
Yes poems. Childish scribbles perhaps, but wit and mischief in every line.
Well. (beat) He’1l write no more.
No. And nor shall I. She looks at him. Turns and walks away.
It’s not Hamnet you mourn. It’s yourself.
I mourn my son! She keeps walking.
Now. You mourn him now. At the time you wrote The Merry Wives of Windsor. He tries to return to his digging but gives it up. He lay aside his spade and heads into the lane.
Will is at the door of Susanna’s house. He knocks and Sus answers.
Will is walking with Susanna. Elizabeth runs about playin
Its an adjustment. She must learn to be a wife once more. They walk on. Birds twitter. Elizabeth laughs and skips.  33 34 All Is True - Shooting Script 12.
My husband thinks you’ve come home to die.
Really? I’ve just bought a pension. I can’t die for at least ten years or I’ll be ruined. A small moment of levity between them.
So why are you come home? No more stories left to write?
Susanna, I have lived so long in imaginary worlds that I believe I've lost sight of what is real, of what is true.
Judith says nothing is true.
Judith is 28 and a spinster. That is true. Will walks on. Susanna calls after him.
Will you write no more Father? Will either doesn’t hear or simply doesn’t answer.

The work in the garden goes on. Will still clearing and rearranging the existing plants. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - DAY 34 Anne and Judith are preparing food together. Will is seen them both in the garden beyond.
When Father dies I will be destitute.
No child. A third of his fortune comes to me, while I live.
While you live. You’re older than him, remember.  All Is True - Shooting Script 13.
Susanna will never see you want.
Susanna will obey her husband. I will get nothing. Which is what I deserve.
Judith. If you won’t forgive yourself. How can you expect God to?
I don’t.
Will and Susanna have arrived at a glade with a body of water.
I ran here on the day I was sacked from the school.
I know Father.
When I was the son of an Alderman I had a free education. But the son of a thief? I thought my world had ended. Will looks about him. Remembering.
I loved this place. You children loved it too.
Yes, we came here every day. Although Hamnet never went in the water. He wasn’t bold like Judith. Or even me.

But his mind was bold. (memories) Once he brought me here, to show me what he’d written. I told him then that I was the proudest father in the Kingdom. I still am. Will turns away. Susanna so sad for him.  36 37 38 39 All Is True - Shooting Script 14.
Big broad sweeping vista from the garden. The leaves in t Green Wood are turning. Time is passing.
Will works on his garden. Now digging, cutting turf, Gardening is hard. Anne emerges.
Husband! Its Sunday.
Sunday?

This isn’t London. If you miss church here they fine you. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM — MORNING 38 Susanna and John and Elizabeth have arrived in their Sund best. Judith and Anne also. Will comes down buttoning his smart doublet trying to be the happy family man.
Well well! Here we all are. How sweet you look Elizabeth. Shall we be off?
I must needs first answer nature’s call.
Nature seems to like your company. It calls every five minutes. Hall scowls and leaves, unbuttoning his cod piece as he g he’s in a hurry.
The family are leaving the house for Church. Will pauses outside the front door, picking up little Elizabeth he sh her the Coat of Arms above the door.
What’s that Little Lizzie? The little girl is proud to know the answer.
Our Coat of Arms Grandfather.  40 4l All Is True - Shooting Script 15.

That's right. Which hangs upon the second best house in Stratford. The house of a gentleman. The woman are unimpressed but Will takes great satisfacti and casts another look at the shield before leading the family to church.

Featuring the picturesque church of Holy Trinity. INT. HOLY TRINITY CHURCH —- MORNING 4l The congregation are at Sunday Service. The Shakespeare’s enter. Many townsfolk tip their hats to an important fami Will is pleased to accept their greetings. They take their places in the second row. In the far more impressive side box are the Lucy family, the grandest fam of them all. Sir Thomas Lucy nods curtly at Will. Will fe this slight.
Ah Shakespeare! Another Sunday and still you occupy your family pew. I pray that you are never obliged to vacate it. As your Father was. This cuts.

I am not my Father Sir Thomas. The congregation continues to assemble. Rafe Smith, a haberdasher enters. Susanna catches his eye and there is brief moment of connection. Will notices this. John Hall also notices it too. He whispers to Susanna.

I am happy that you have friends in the town Susanna. But kindly be discreet about it. Susanna reddens, there is a secret here. A group of giggling girls surround a handsome man, Tom Quiney. Quiney sees Judith and gives her a broad smile. S does not return it. The girls sneer, they don’t like Judi The Puritans don’t like Tom Quiney. The little congregati is a labyrinth of small town conflicts and alliances. We sense a story in every face, only some of them will we follow. The Vicar, Edward Woolmer enters. Music begins.  42 43 All Is True - Shooting Script 16.
Will works in his garden. He makes slow but steady progre Now cutting shapes and tracks in the earth with knife and trowel. Messy and content. John Hall approaches.
I joy to see you dig Sir. At last given up on your plays to distract the mob from our Lord. Will considers this for a moment. A lark sings.
Does the Lark song distract you from your God John?
Of course not. It is evidence of God.

Well then. Perhaps for some, I was a Lark? Will offers this with gentle twinkle. John Hall is slight floored, he is about to attempt an answer but realizes he hasn't really got one. He gathers his dignity.
I came to ask a favour Father in Law. But I am loath to distract a man from his labours. Will you call when you are done with your garden? Will nods. John departs.

People go about their business. Susanna walks to the tave She is greeted with respect as a wealthy doctors wife. Ha are tipped. Susanna passes Tom Quiney’s Wine and Tobacco shop. Quiney calls out cheerfully.

Good day to you Mrs. Hall. Tell your sister I have a fine Rhenish Wine delivered. She may have a bottle gratis for a single smile. Susanna puts her nose in the air with disdain and walks o  44 45 46 47 48 All Is True - Shooting Script 17.
The Tavern is also a Post House. Susanna enters and approaches the Landlady.

Package for you Mrs Hall. Frank! A nervous boy rushes forward but he is clumsy and trips. drops it and inside a bottle is heard to break. As the boy tries to gather up the parcel spots of silver liquid are seen amongst the straw. A man is watching. It is John Lane. He drinks sullenly.
Mercury Mrs. Hall?
My husband is a doctor.
She said the parcel was for you. John Lane looks once more at the mercury and turns back t his drink. Susanna, begins furiously to gather up what is left of her parcel.
Will is entering John and Susanna’s house. INT. HALL’S CROFT - DAY 46 John is appealing to Will.
The reformation is but half completed Father in Law. The Vicar of Holy Trinity is a recalcitrant. It is intolerable.
John Lane sullenly drinks his ale, crosses himself discre and leaves the Tavern. INT. HALL’S CROFT - DAY 48 John Hall and Will continue their conversation.  All Is True - Shooting Script 18.
You are an influential man. If you were to lend your voice to ours. Will considers.
Susanna is walking past the shops. She pauses outside a haberdashery, then enters. Rafe Smith (35) is at the coun
Good day to you Mr. Smith.
Mrs. Hall. There is moment. A connection. A spark exists here.
I need cloth. A loose weave. To make a summer dress. Black.
Black? For summer? Perhaps this blue.
My husband does not approve of fancy stuff.
If your husband had his way Mrs. Hall my shop would be a very dull place. All in mourning and nobody dead. Tension crackles between them.
Our Saviour wore only simple cloth, and he was divine.
As are you Susanna. In any cloth. Susanna reddens.
Mr. Smith. I am a married woman.
Unhappily.
That is not... I should tell my husband.  All Is True - Shooting Script 19.
Will you?
(beat) He knows.
Susanna is emerging from the Haberdashers. John Lane watc Across the street Quiney in his wine shop has also seen. a small town. Everybody knows everybody. Secrets are hard hide.
The kitchen. Will dines with Anne and Judith.
John Hall wants my help to remove Woolmer as Vicar of Holy Trinity I thought he knew me better.
He thinks you like him.
I’m a good actor. Perhaps Anne takes this in a different way to what Will intended.
I try to like him. For Sue’s sake. But John is a...
Hypocritical shit.
A Puritan.

That’s funny isn’t it? A Puritan, who wants to close all the theatres, will have all of William Shakespeare’s estate - Don’t you think that’s funny? I think it’s funny. Will is taken aback by her gleefully angry tone.  52 53 54 55 56 All Is True - Shooting Script 20. INT. HALL’S CROFT - EVENING 52 John Hall slumbers by the fire. Susanna rises and quietly makes for the door. EXT. HALL’S CROFT - EVENING 53 It is dark. The front door opens and Susanna slips out. Across the street John Lane has been watching. Susanna glances about furtively but does not see Lane. She scurri off into the night. Lane follows.
There has been a silence. Now Will answers Judith.
For what it’s worth Judith I have no intention of leaving my estate to John Hall.
No you'll leave it to the sainted Susanna and by law her property is his. As is her body - for all the use he makes of it! Even in her wild mood Judith knows she’s gone too far.
Rafe Smith’s Haberdashery. Susanna steals through the sha and up to the door. Smith lets her in. John Lane is watch
Will, Judith and Anne.
You are grown hard Judith. There was a time when you were such a simple, joyful soul.
Was I Father? When was that? Will doesn’t answer.
Before Hamnet died? Is that it? (beat) Before Hamnet died. And I survived.  57 58 59 60 All Is True - Shooting Script 21.
Judith. Don’t.
It’s what he thinks. Every time he reads those bloody poems, which aren’t even that good! He thinks why did she survive not him?
Judith.

The golden boy is gone and he’s left with the girl. The useless, pointless girl. Oh she was a pretty thing once that girl. A simple joyful soul. But look at her now? Angry bitch. Still hanging around. Why did the wrong twin die. Will doesn’t answer. Because he knows there is some truth what she says. INT. HALL’S CROFT - NIGHT 57 John Hall still sleeps before the fire. Susanna opens the door and creeps back in. As she passes on her way to the stair his eyes open. He wasn’t asleep at all and she knew too. They stare at each other but say nothing.
The lonely candles at the windows. A passer by looks up t the great house. INT. ANNES’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 59 Anne prepares for bed. Will appears at the door.
I never gave her cause. I never said an unkind word.
You've spent so long putting words into other people’s mouths, you think it only matters what is said. She closes the door on him.
The locked up shop. No light.  61 62 63 64 65 66 67 All Is True - Shooting Script
Rafe sits alone on his bed, deep in thought. The bed is 22. 61 unmade, the covers rumpled. He gathers them up and breath them in.

Darkness. Cold. INT. SUSANNA’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Susanna lies in bed. Eyes wide open. She hears pissing. INT. JOHN HALL’S CHAMBER - NIGHT John is pissing in his chamber pot. He is uncomfortable. Unhappily he returns to bed.
All asleep bar one. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Judith sits alone drinking.
Time is passing. Will works on his garden. He is rolling lengths of turf in front of a rich bank of flowers. Now an earnest young student appears at the gate. Henry.
Mr. Shakespeare? I don’t want to pester you.
Good. Excellent news. Cheerio then.
It’s just that I wanted to ask...
The best way to get started as a writer is to start writing. Cheerio.
No really could I... 62 63 64 65 66 67  All Is True - Shooting Script 23.

I don’t have a favourite play. I admire all my fellow dramatists equally. And yes I do think women should be allowed to perform the female roles as is the practice on the continent. Now please. If you'll excuse me. Will returns to his digging. Defeated, Henry almost leave but doesn’t.
I have come all the way from Cambridge to see you. I left my college without leave.
(wearily) And that was your choice. Henry gets the message. Starts to walk away. Stops and tu One last go.
I just want to ask - how you knew.
Knew what?
Everything.
My friend I don’t even know how to keep the slugs out of the Hollyhocks.
(impatient) The world is full of gardeners. I mean everything that matters. Will raises an eyebrow at this.
There is no corner of this world which you have not explored. No geography of the soul you can not navigate. How? How do you know? Finally Will is forced to engage.
What I know. If I know it. And I don’t say that I do. I have - (a moment to consider) Imagined.  All Is True - Shooting Script 24.
But they say you left school at fourteen... You’ve never travelled. Imagined? From what?
From my self!
Your self?

Yes! Everything I’ve ever done. Everything I’ve ever seen, every book I’ve ever read, and every conversation I have ever had, including, God help me, this one. You will find the whole of me in every word I ever wrote. My thoughts, my feelings, my dreams. If you would be a playwright and speak for others then speak first for yourself. Search within. Consider the contents of your own soul. Your humanity. For that is the business of the theatre. Everything else is just stage directions. Henry is trying to take it all in. Will takes a little pi and tries to sum it up in a more kindly tone.
Write what you are, what you know, what you feel and what you can imagine my friend. And if you are honest then whatever you write all is true. Henry wants to reply but can’t think what to say.

Now please. If you can’t save my hollyhocks, leave me to mourn the dead. Will returns to his digging. Henry is confused but also strangely inspired. He knows he should leave but can not resist pushing his luck.
Then why.... Will looks up. Fierce now. The boy’s being rude. Henry returns his stare.  68 69 All Is True - Shooting Script 25.
Why did you stop? Why do you write no more? A beat. Is Will considering an answer? Another beat. If h was he doesn’t give it.
Cheerio. Will turns his back. This time it’s final.
Judith approaches Tom Quiney’s wine and tobacco shop. INT. QUINEY’S WINE SHOP - DAY 69 Judith enters. Her usual cold self. But she knows Quiney.
Good morning Tom Quiney. A barrel of Huffcap ale and three flagons of Malmesey wine to be delivered to New Place if you would. On our account. Tom is a cheerful, flirtatious fellow.
Your usual order and my usual reply. Marry me Judith. I would help bring back your smile.
Yes and every other maid in the county’s. You chase them all.
But I only ever propose to one.
I'd think you'd tire of it. Quiney’s cheerful mask slips a little.

I remember a girl. The prettiest and happiest in town. And I remember her laugh and I remember kiss chase. I'd like to see the woman that girl should have become. Because it surely isn’t you.  70 71 All Is True - Shooting Script 26.
Time for a break. Will sits amongst his gardening tools. has his satchel of Hamnet’s verse and is reading. Some li which catches his eye. It makes him smile, almost laugh.
Oh my son. My pretty chicken. My golden lad. Anne emerges.

It’s Sunday. Will carefully puts his precious pages away. INT. HOLY TRINITY CHURCH —- MORNING 71 The congregation are at Sunday Service. The Lucy family arrive. Will attempts to greet them as equals, but again Thomas merely nods curtly at the Shakespeare's. Will pain and embarrassed. Rafe Smith enters. For a moment he catches Susanna’s eye. they share a secret. Will notices this and turns to look at Hall who is also staring at Rafe Smith. The dissolute John Lane is at the back. Tense. Sweating, perhaps discreetly drinking. He stares at Susanna and the Rafe Smith. Building up to something. The Vicar Edward Woolmer begins the service. Quiney bustles in late with a pretty girl, Margaret Wheel following. Both a little disheveled. Now the service is almost over.

Our reading today was from the first chapter of Corinthians “I beseech ye bretheren, in the name of Jesus, that there be no divisions among you” (beat) There is division in our town. The Puritans protest against the old ways. The feastings, the merriment and customs long practised. Some of you resent this I know but I charge you remember Corinthians! These good Christians act from honest faith. They are upright citizens, decent and pious....  All Is True - Shooting Script 27. Suddenly John Lane jumps up.
Are they Mr. Woolmer! Are they? Or are they fornicators! General shock
There is wickedness in this church Mr. Woolmer! Puritan wickedness. He points at Susanna.

I have seen Susanna Hall creep from her husband’s house to Rafe Smith’s chamber in the night! Card: In the summer of 1613 John Lane, yeoman of Stratfor publicly accused Shakespeare’s elder daughter Susanna of infidelity with Rafe Smith the Haberdasher. Susanna mortified. Will stunned. The congregation in upro etc. John Hall leaps to his feet.
This slander will be answered!

This slander will be proved! You'll no more tell us how best to save our souls Doctor Hall. Not while your Puritan wives fornicate worse than whores and then send to London for Mercury to physic what they got of it! Card: John Lane compounded his charge by stating that Sus had contracted Gonorrhea. The tumult grows.

Silence! This is a house of God! And I am master here! Edward Woolmer the Vicar glares at John Hall. Sensing a dangerous rival. Will is red faced with anger and shame. He catches the patronizing look of Sir Thomas Lucy, half censure, half p As the congregation bustle out, all talking of the scanda Sir Thomas Lucy pauses over Will.  74 All Is True - Shooting Script 28.
Well well Sir. You Shakespeare's are never far from a scandal are you? Will is mortified. Sir Thomas glances at Susanna.

I suppose she gets it from her Grandfather. Fixed the price of Wool didn’t he? Bad business. And illegal money lending to boot! Goodness! He was a busy fellow. No wonder they chucked him off the council. Will who is pretty dumb struck. Anne however hit’s back.

Every family has it’s dark Horse, Sir Thomas, Even the Lucy’s. Or perhaps it is another Thomas Lucy who's niece ran off with a serving man in 1600? Sir Thomas, moves on in fury. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - EVENING 74 The family assemble. All sit in shocked silence. Will ent
I have instructed my lawyers. We shall sue him for slander.
A public trial?
It is a public slander.
John Lane is a dangerous man. We can be sure he did not stage his attack without some idea of how to prove it. Beat. Will turns to Susanna.
Prove it?
How can you ask?
Because your husband fears he can.  75 76 All Is True - Shooting Script 29. John Hall is thrown by this. He had not expected Will to place such an astute interpretation on his remark.
I mean that I fear he has constructed a convincing lie. Judith seems almost to revel in Susanna’s discomfort.
Well now. What a disaster. And that it should befall such a fine and blameless family as ours. Will is determined.
The Shakespeare’s will not be ruined twice.
Susanna hurries along. All eyes turn on her. Very differe from the respect she’s used to. The town seems to be turn against her, reveling in her shame.

A packed court full of gawping towns folk. The Shakespear family enter. Some snigger, some snarl. The Puritan eleme are tight lipped between shame and righteous anger. CARD: The trial of John Lane for the slander of Susanna Shakespeare was convened at The Consistory Court, Worcest
Bring forward the accused. A Clerk stands.
Call John Lane. There is a pause. The Judge is impatient. An officer ente
John Lane is not here you Honour.
Not here!
He has disappeared.  All Is True - Shooting Script 30.

Susanna Shakespeare has been most foully used. The crowd erupts. CARD: John Lane failed to attend his trial. The case bein uncontested, he was convicted of slander, and excommunica 77 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM —- EVENING 77 Anne and Will sit.
Why? Why did this man slander our Sue?
My guess is to damage her husband. John Hall is a Puritan, and would make Holy Trinity and all the town likewise. John Lane on the other hand likes his cakes and ale.
Then why did he not attend the court and press his case? Beat.
I discussed the matter with him.
Discussed? Discussed what?
I asked him if he’d ever seen Titus Andronicus.
Flashback. Will has met John Lane.
What do I know of plays? Get away from me. I shall see you and your whore daughter in Court.
It concerns a Moorish villain named Aaron. And the African who played him was magnificent and terrifying.  79 80 All Is True - Shooting Script 31.
A performance of Titus. Intimidating passion and violence

To kill a man, or else devise his death, Ravish a maid, or plot the way to do it. Accuse some innocent and forswear myself, Set deadly enmity between two friends, Make poor men's cattle break their necks; Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night, And bid the owners quench them with their tears. Oft have I digg'd up dead men from their graves, And set them upright at their dear friends' doors, Tut, I have done a thousand dreadful things As willingly as one would kill a fly, And nothing grieves me heartily indeed But that I cannot do ten thousand more.
Flashback. Will still talks with John Lane who is pretty scared.
Mighty like a lion. Strong as a bear. I saw this man tear the heart from a fool who wronged him and eat it raw! Lane is fearful.
And yet - he could be tender too. And one day his wild heart was tamed. He loved my daughter.
Susanna?
Ay. Susanna. Their love could never be of course. (MORE )
81 82 All Is True - Shooting Script 32.

But he swore that if ever she had need, his sword, his claws and his teeth would either defend her or kill for her. Should I tell him of Susanna’s current distress? John Lane is suitably nervous. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 81 Will and Anne.
Will. I saw Titus. Aaron was played by the sweetest chap you could hope to meet. I talked to him for an hour afterwards at the George Inn.
Yes, He was a lovely fellow Wife, but John Lane doesn’t know that, and I’ve never let the truth get in the way of a good story. A moment of levity. Anne for the first time a little less cold.
All men fear what they do not know Anne and I’1l wager John Lane has never laid eyes on an African. Anne once more reflective.
Do you think there was any truth in it? In what Lane said? About Susanna?

Well. There is coldness between them. We’ve seen that. Something they both recognize in themselves. INT. HALL’S CROFT - EVENING 82 Susanna and John Hall sit in grim silence. She stitches, reads the Bible. Will’s voice-over comments on the scene.
‘Tis five years since she and John have had a child. John rises.  83 84 85 86 87 All Is True - Shooting Script 33.
I’m going to bed. Good night. He leaves. Susanna sad and alone.

And Susanna certainly knows this Rafe Smith.... INT. RAFE SMITH’S SHOP - MORNING 83 A past moment. Susanna is buying material. Rafe holds som cloth against her body as if to say “look, this would sui you”. It is physical, fun, she blushes coyly.
Another past moment. Susanna is hurrying from the tavern the broken package of Mercury.

She did send to London for Mercury. Mercury is a cure for Pox. A drop or two more falls to the street as she hurries alo Susanna is nervous and embarrassed. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 85 Will and Anne together.
Sue is not poxed Will. I’d know.

He then?....a poxed man is ever pissing. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - MORNING 86 Flashback to the Sunday morning they went to church when said he must answer nature’s call. Susanna has just made comment about nature liking Hall’s company.

Have you some objection to my visiting the privy? INT. HALL’S CROFT - NIGHT 87 John Hall in his bed chamber, sweating and in pain. He ta a little bottle and swigs at it.  All Is True - Shooting Script 34. 88 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - EVENING 88 Back with Will and Anne’s conversation.
Is that why she bares no more children? Did she seek comfort elsewhere?
Susanna stealing into Smith’s house. 90 INT. SMITH’S BED - NIGHT 90 Smith and Susanna are making passionate love.
The Devil will take both our souls for this.
But we go there by way of Heaven. 91 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 91 Will and Anne still talking.
Susanna is a God fearing woman. She would not betray her husband. Judith appears at the door. She’s been listening.
Maybe it wasn’t a betrayal?
Judith?
Maybe he told her to do it. 92 INT. HALL’S CROFT - EVENING 92 Susanna and John Hall sit.

It will be either your womb or your sister’s which secures your father’s fortune. John stares at her. Then returns to reading his Bible.  93 94 95 All Is True - Shooting Script 35. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 93 Judith confronting a shocked Anne and Will.
Well it’s a thought isn’t it? And frankly Father, if you got a grandson by it. Would you care if it were true? Will decides not to answer this.
I care that Susanna is free from slander. That you may be sure is true.
Nothing is ever true.
Once more Will walks with Susanna.
You think my husband is trying to whore me to get a bigger house? Will a bit flummoxed. Susanna is not usually so forthrigh

We should not seek to lift the veil on other peoples marriages Father. All are complex. To understand one, you have to live it. (beat) And you’re hardly an expert there. Susanna walks on. Will can only follow, chastened.

A change of season. Time is passing. Will works in his garden. Some progress has been made on design. Some curves, and turns in the rails of turf, but hard. He is hot. He is very tired. The heat of the sun starts to play tricks with his eyes as he shades them fro the glare. As he works a boy leans on the fence. It is th boy from the tavern, he masks his eyes against the Sun, h face once more in shadow.
Got any berries?  All Is True - Shooting Script 36.
Eventually. I have planted a mulberry tree.
Well then, you’ve got time to finish my story while we wait. The boy has removed his hands. For the first time his fac clear. Will’s eyes focus through the haze. Is it his son?
Hamnet? Is it you? The boy seems half lost in the haze.
I wrote you another poem today. Would you like to hear it?
I want nothing more in this world. The boys cheerfulness suddenly gives way to rising anger.

Well you'll have to wait won’t you! Like I waited. I had a poem before for you but you never came! The sickness came instead and still you didn’t come though Mother promised you would! Now the boy emerges from the haze but in a horrifying vis transformation he becomes a plague victim. Great sores on face. Will recoils in horror as the boy confronts him.
I had a poem for you! You never came. Will recoils in horror as the boy confronts him.
Hamnet! Anne’s voice intrudes upon the vision.
Will? Will spins around to her.
You're shouting.... He turns back, there is no boy. There was no boy.  96 97 All Is True - Shooting Script 37.
He was here Anne.
He'll always be here Will. Now we see that from an upper window Judith has been watc the scene. Again there are tears on her cheeks.
The gorgeous meadow in the last rays. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 97 Will dines with Anne and Judith. The mood is sombre.
In London now the plays are just finished. Will is doing his best.
Taverns full.
If you’re missing London. Why don’t you go back there? This is getting hard for Will. He is prepared to eat humb pie but this is relentless.
Do you wish I would Daughter?
It doesn’t matter what I wish but what you wish. And it isn’t to be with us.
What do you mean?
You’ve come back to mourn Hamnet! To mourn your blessed departed son and dig a bloody garden for him.
That’s enough Judith.
We mourned him Father! We mourned him when he died. And we mourned him thereafter. (MORE )
98 All Is True - Shooting Script 38.
Now it seems we must begin again as if his grave was freshly dug because suddenly you've found time to mourn him too!
Hold your tongue! Respect your Father even if you can’t respect yourself. That was a hard blow. Judith is in many ways a sorry sigh Careless of her appearance. Often with a glass in her han
If you are done with mourning him at least honour his memory.
How can you say I don’t?
Then start living up to it! If you can not match his talent, try to match his goodness and his diligence. You are wasting your life! Judith stares at her father.
I know what you think’s the purpose of a woman’s life. I know what you want from me.

Seasons change. In the montage, we see a quiet Will getti on with building this garden as best he can. Thoughtful, if all that Judith has said sits with him. Preoccupies hi Occasionally he looks about him. For signs of the boy. Th are none. Buds blossom. Leafs fall. Will is measuring parts of the garden using twine and whe He is assisted by a serving girl, Maria. Will counts off yards.
Maria is inclined to chat.
Bit of a change from making plays in London. Will leans on his stick, happy for a break. He likes her. considers her point.  All Is True - Shooting Script 38A.
In some ways yes Maria. In others. Rather similar.
Similar? I don’t see how. A light of enthusiasm begins to shine.
Well, today we take the measure of our stage.
A garden ain't a play. Will enjoying himself. A relief from the grim family mood
A play, a garden, a fresh baked loaf like the ones you bake each morning. All begin with an idea. A compulsion to create a thing of beauty, or need.
Bread begins with yeast and flour.

Exactly! Now you're getting it! Ingredients! Brambles, bushes. Yeast, flour. Verses, players. They're nothing without a dream! Which will not be denied and which endures in spite of all adversity. The weather will turn, the bugs will infest. The oven will cool and the flour will mould. Your fellow worker - in my case, a brilliant lunatic actor called Dick Burbage - will interfere and demand a bigger show for a smaller budget, anda shorter play with a much longer part for himself. And all of these trials must be countered and overcome without ever loosing sight of the dream itself!
And what does it feel like when all of that works?
How does fresh baked bread smell?
Wonderful.  All Is True - Shooting Script 38B. He smiles at her as if to say ‘exactly!’. That’s his poin Maria is smiling too at his half comical passion.
Will is hurrying up the garden path. Excited, he has a le in his hand. 100 INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - MORNING 100 Will rushes in. Anne is cooking.
Anne! Anne. Anne. The Earl of Southampton makes a progress North. (MORE )
Anne does All Is True - Shooting Script 39.
He writes that since he passes this way he will spend an hour or two in talk with me. not share Will’s excitement.
Did you hear me wife? The Earl of Southampton.
I heard you. And I recall the day I first heard about your friend the Earl of Southampton.
Wife?
Same day I heard there’d been a book of poems published. Sonnets they told me. Will is completely thrown. He was not expecting this. Will ata
Perhaps you thought because I couldn’t read them I wouldn’t mind. But plenty of people can read. Even in our little town. Including one of your own daughters.
Anne - Those sonnets were published illegally. Without my knowledge or consent.
But you wrote ‘em Will. And people read ‘em. And after they’d read them they started asking “Who are they then?” “Who’s this dark lady he’s so in love with?”
They were just poems...
And the Beautiful boy Will? The Fair youth? loss.
Don’t answer. I didn’t want to know then and I don’t want to know now. (MORE )
107 All Is True - Shooting Script 40.
But I do know who some people said he was. And now it seems he’s to come to my house a’calling. Will pretty shame faced.
All these years you’ve worried about your reputation Will. Have you even once considered mine?
Will and family at their gate. All in their best awaiting great visitor. Will is very excited.
I will introduce you but do not address him unless he addresses you. On my nod must you all depart and leave us to our talk.
He’s just a man Father.
He is an Earl Susanna. (to Elizabeth) Do you hear that Lizzie, your Grandpa is to drink wine with an Earl.
Because you are a gentleman! The little girl points excitedly at the Coat of Arms.
Yes! Because I am a gentleman! Sir Thomas Lucy, his wife and servant approach on foot, a in their Sunday best.

Ah Shakespeare. I heard word of your distinguished visitor. My men tell me that he is even now approaching the town. Of course you will introduce me. Will taken aback. He hadn’t expected this. Anne assumes h will tell Lucy to mind his own business, but Will buckles superior rank and says nothing.
I shall suggest he comes on to Charlecote to take his ease. (MORE )
All Is True - Shooting Script 41.
Bit more what he’s used to. Naturally I shall ask that you join us... (glancing at Anne) Just you I think. We shouldn’t wish to tire his Grace. Clattering horses are heard.
Welcome to Stratford Upon Avon Your Grace. The very impressive Earl of Southampton eyes Lucy.
And you are?
Sir Thomas Lucy of Charlecote Manor your Grace and Member of Parliament for this district. May I have the honour of introducing my wife....
Have we business?
Well I...
Is there some petition which you are come to present?
Oh no Your Grace I thought only to invite you to...
Then kindly remove yourself, Sir Thomas. I want none of your company. I am here to visit the greatest man in the kingdom. After His Majesty of course. Southampton turns to Will.
Will!  All Is True - Shooting Script 42.

head_text.subj: INT. THE GREAT HALL NEW PLACE

text: Will and Southampton talking by the fire.
Damn impudence. A grubby little Member of Parliment. They'll sell a knighthood to anybody these days.
He has snubbed me many times.

But why do you let him snub you Will? What is he? The son of a son. Nothing more. All his pride and strut comes from no greater achievement than having been spat from the dick of a previous nonentity. I’m the same.
No! (N.B Wriothesley pronounced ‘Wrizzly”, as in grizzly.)

I’m the son of a son Will. Henry Wriothesley son of Henry Wriothesley and if I were not the son of Henry Wriothesley then your Thomas Lucy, son of Thomas Lucy would not grace me with a sneer. You on the other hand are...
The son of a thief.

The son of Apollo! God of poetry! God of truth! The finest, the most complete and the most beautiful mind I'll warrant that ever existed in this world. Will is of course delighted and deeply moved. Southampton stares at him for a few moments.
So why are you so small Will?
Small?
Why are you are such a little man?  All Is True - Shooting Script 42a.
Your Grace?  All Is True - Shooting Script 43.
You can enchant the multitude with the scratch of your quill. Yet you cringe before a cur like Sir Thomas Lucy.
Cringe?
Your talent has a greater scope than all the other poets combined and yet you’ve led the smallest life.
I don’t think I’ve led a small life your Grace.
Oh come now Will! Compared to Kyd? Or Marlowe! What a man. What a life! Spy! Adventurer! Fucked for England! Boys. Girls. Boys and girls. He knew how to live.
He is dead of course, My Lord. So, you know, win some lose some.
They are all dead Will. Marlowe, Greene...
Who called me upstart...
.+..Crow! You see! Still you care. Still it rankles. Kyd, Nashe, Spenser, Oxford. All dead. Booze and passion, sex and violence killed ‘em all. Life killed them. And you? You survived.
Yes. I survived.
With your nice house...
Several houses.
And your Coat of Arms. How much did that cost you Will?  All Is True - Shooting Script 43A.
Twenty pounds.  All Is True - Shooting Script 44.

Twenty pounds. The man who wrote Hamlet and Henry the fifth, Macbeth and Romeo and Juliet paid twenty pounds for the name of gentlemen. Oh Will. Will. Why do you care? Will pours more wine and thinks about his answer.
My father was once fined for not attending Church. Can you guess why he didn’t go?
Priest too Protestant? I’ve heard it rumoured there’s a whiff of Papery about you Shakespeare’s.
Nothing so spiritual. He could not attend church because he owed money to most of the congregation. A beat. Then Southampton roars with laughter.
I think I’d have liked your Dad!
Yes. People did. They drink in silence for a moment.
You must write again Will. London needs you. We have only Jonson now.
Who laughs at me because I speak no Greek and don’t care wether Bohemia has a coast.
Christ Will why do you care what he thinks! You wrote King Lear.

I care because it matters Your Grace! In England it matters. I have what I have upon my own merit and for that I am suspect! Perhaps I will always be suspect. But I have my money and I have my houses and I have my Coat of Arms.  All Is True - Shooting Script 45.
You have your verse! Great Christ man you have your poetry. Such poetry. Such beautiful, beautiful poetry.... Southampton’s eyes grow a little misty.
And some of it. Some of it was writ for me. A long beat, they stare at each other.
Yes your Grace. For you. Another beat. There is love here.

I have grown old. As you said in your sonnets that I would, you bastard. But the beauty I inspired in you will be forever young. And a thousand years from now when people read those lines, I shall be young. Alive still in the minds of lovers yet unborn.
They were only meant for you Your Grace. Not for any other living soul nor any yet to live. Just you.
It was only flattery of course. Flattery that was my due.
Yes. Just flattery. Except. I spoke from deep within my heart. They stare deep at one another.
Well. I was younger then. Younger and prettier.
Beautiful your Grace. As you will ever be. When, in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes, I all alone beweep my outcast state, And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries, (MORE )
All Is True - Shooting Script

And look upon myself and curse my fate, Wishing me like to one more rich in hope, Featured like him, like him with friends possessed, Desiring this man’s art and that man’s scope, With what I most enjoy contented least; Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising, Haply I think on thee, and then my state, (Like to the lark at break of day arising From sullen earth) sings hymns at heaven’s gate; For thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings That then I scorn to change my state with kings.
Yes, well. As I say. Just flattery.
Not flattery. Truth. And I always dared to hope...
Hope Will?
That, perhaps in some small way it was reciprocated. A tiny change of atmosphere. Will doesn’t pick it up.
Reciprocated?
That perhaps you also... Suddenly Southampton’s face is cold.
You forget yourself Will.
As a poet you have no equal. And I, like anyone with brain and heart am your humble servant. (MORE )
109 All Is True - Shooting Script 47.

But as a man Will it is not your place to love me and hanging a twenty pound shield above your door will never make it so. Will is crushed. Southampton’s good humour returns, he sl Will on the back and drains his glass.

I must be off. Goodbye Will Shakespeare. It was the poet I came to visit and it is the poet of whom I take my leave. Southampton stands, Will gets to his feet of course, but is sad, unable to make a merry parting. Southampton smile friendly, conciliatory smile.

When, in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes, I all alone beweep my outcast state, And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries, And look upon myself and curse my fate, Wishing me like to one more rich in hope, Featured like him, like him with friends possessed, Desiring this man’s art and that man’s scope, With what I most enjoy contented least; Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising, Haply I think on thee, and then my state, (Like to the lark at break of day arising From sullen earth) sings hymns at heaven’s gate; For thy sweet love remembered such wealth brings That then I scorn to change my state with kings

The Southampton party leaves. His Grace does not look bac Will stands very still watching the procession go. The re of the family start to move back into the house. Anne sta there too, a little apart. There is nothing to say.  110 111 112 All Is True - Shooting Script 48.
Judith approaching Tom Quiney’s wine and tobacco shop. INT. QUINEY’S WINE SHOP - MORNING 111 Judith enters. Quiney as ever jolly and boisterous.
A glass Miss Shakespeare? To toast this sunny morning?
I need no excuse for a glass of wine Mr. Quiney. Beat.
There is another pleasure, equally heady.
And plenty of country girls for you to get it with.
Your looks won’t last forever Jude.
And I shall be glad when they’re gone because I shall be no more bothered by the likes of you.
Will has been working hard. Working to forget. Will and Douglas are at work again on the garden border. are planting grasses where previously they measured. Doug begins another conversation.
Sir. I suppose you’ve writ down all sorts of men.
Indeed.
And now you grow flowers.
Trying.  113 All Is True - Shooting Script 48A.
Which do you like better?
Which do you?
Flowers Sir. They’re beautiful.
Aren’t people?
Some. I suppose But they’re cruel and selfish too.
And flowers?
Aren't.

But every flower fights for the light. One will strangle and starve another to survive. All they care about is their place in the Sun. Every one will put itself before it’s neighbour. But sometimes, we do not. Once in a while, god knows not very often, we’ll reach to help another up towards the Sun. I like flowers. But I like people better. Douglas smiles he likes the answer. They return to work. Later Anne brings Will some water. An arm round the shoul An attempt to restore normality. They slowly walk back towards the house. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - EVENING 113 The family sit.

I notice that your friend the Earl didn’t bring his wife with him on his travels. Perhaps he doesn’t find female company to his taste. If this was a jibe Will ignores it.  All Is True - Shooting Script 49.
I’m sure that His Grace and the Countess Elizabeth are most happy in their marriage. Possible discreetly raised eye brows from Anne and Judith
As I would wish you to be Judith. Why are you still unwed? You are pretty enough I think.
I don’t.
Then look in your glass.
I have no glass.
I didn’t like the person I saw in it. Will getting a little irritated at her endless negativity
Good God Daughter that’s a bleak thought since the only company you keep is your own.
But there it is.
But what of children? All women want children.
Apparently.
Don’t you want a child?
Do you want me to replace Hamnet for you Father? This is brutal. Will absorbs the blow. Tries to be reasonable.
I meant for your own sake. A husband, children. For comfort, companionship.  All Is True - Shooting Script 50.
She's seen that marriage may not bring you either. Will’s anger begins slowly to boil.
Is that it Judith? Have you seen your mother’s misery, and thought better to be a spinster than shackled to a man who neglects you?
I did not say I was miserable.
No wife you didn’t, but though I put words into other people's mouths, I too can occasionally see beyond what is merely said. Anne shrugs. Quite suddenly Will explodes. Fist on table.
And I will take no more of this! I have worked ceaselessly on behalf of this family...
On your own behalf-

And I am head of this family! I have given you a fine house and servants. I have sent you money all your life. Is that not Comfort? You have two beautiful daughters, a brilliant son and a husband who though absent, kept you always in his thoughts! Is that not companionship? In abundance? Anne’s face suggests this is a stretch. Will doubles down

I have raised this family up! Through my genius I have brought fame and fortune to this house. Yes my genius! Would you have had me ignore that? Ignore a gift from God almighty so that I could be a bloody glove maker, and you might feel a bit more appreciated! It’s a hard blow. Will’s defense is to go deeper.  All Is True - Shooting Script 51.

Hamnet died and I wasn’t here. I know that. The plague took him and I wasn’t here. But the plague has taken millions and it would have taken him whether I was in London, or in Stratford, or on that godforsaken highway. We lost our boy! We lost our beautiful, brilliant brilliant boy and I wasn’t there... Anne has merely bit her lip at all of this. Now, suddenly is Judith who answers Will. Jumping up and shouting.
Hamnet wasn’t brilliant!
What? A beat. Judith knows she has begun something which now ca not be stopped.
He was beautiful but he wasn’t brilliant.
Judith. Don’t.
What do you mean?
I wrote them.
Wrote what?
Judith I said don’t!
The poems. There’s no turning back. Judith grabs at Will’s satchel a takes out the precious sheaf of papers.
The verses you hold so dear! With wit and mischief in every line. I made them up. Hamnet only wrote them down.
She helped him a little that’s all.  All Is True - Shooting Script 52.
I made them up! All of them. Hamnet was sweet and kind but he was no poet.
No! He was....
He wasn’t!
Brilliant.... Anne realizes the game is up.
No Will! He was just an ordinary little boy. You would have seen it in a moment had you ever looked.
I looked!
And you saw what you wanted to see. You saw yourself!
Judith! Enough.
Myself?

A boy with a mind as big and bold as yours. But happy, with a father who appreciated his genius. Well Hamnet might not have been a genius but he was clever enough to know that he could never live up to what you wanted him to be! He dreaded your visits! Will is devastated. Anne tries to explain.

We didn’t plan it. Not when it began. It was only that Jude was always making up stories, conjuring rhymes... One day Hamnet wrote one of hers down for practise with his pen. You found it and thought it was his and praised him so.... Will tries to come to terms with all this. Judith has been holding the sheaf of papers.  114 All Is True - Shooting Script 53.
So are they worthless now?
They aren’t his.
Will you read them no more? Sit in the Sun and chuckle at their wit?
They are not his.

No! They’re mine and so I will do what I please with them. She throws them on the fire. For a moment it seems as if will jump up and pull them out. But he doesn’t. He watche them burn. INT. THE SHAKESPEARE’S KITCHEN - NIGHT 114 It is very late. Will now sits alone. The empty satchel i his lap. Anne appears.
Judith tried to teach herself to write you know. After Hamnet died. But she never had the patience. Not like Sue. A moment of silence.

I should have liked to have been able to write a few letters. Particularly married to you! Remember our wedding day? Me, older and pregnant, you this strange, clever lad of 18. I knew what people thought. I couldn’t even sign the register, had to make a stupid mark. I felt so foolish. Will looks at her, he hadn’t known that.

Then you went off and become the greatest writer in England! With a wife at home who couldn’t read a single word. I sometimes wondered wether that bothered you at all. (beat) But why would it? You were hardly here.  All Is True - Shooting Script 54. They both sit in the firelight with their thoughts.
Will walks with Susanna.
I didn’t know it was she who wrote the verse. But then Judith and Hamnet were inseparable. I wasn’t allowed into their world.
Why did she never tell me?
Out of loyalty to Hamnet I suppose. He wanted you to believe him brilliant in life. Why would he wish it any less in death?
It was cruel.
Cruel for her I think.
For Judith?
Would you want to be denied credit for your verse? Have people think someone else writ them? Someone better educated?
No. No I shouldn’t like it at all.
Well look at them afresh. Celebrate your living daughter rather than your dead son. Perhaps Judith will finally smile again. Will is beginning to have some understanding of his insensitivity.
She burned them.
Burned them? Why?
Because I am a fool.  All Is True - Shooting Script 55. Will walks on. Susanna follows.
Father. Why do you write no more? Will still does not wish to answer this. But slowly, he tries.

On the morning after the theatre burnt, I stood there, among the ruins, determined to begin again. To write another play. My greatest yet. To open another theatre. Even greater. He pauses. Collecting his thoughts. Susanna listens.

And so I looked inside my self. Into my soul. I looked, as so often I had looked before. And this time... I found - Nothing. There was nothing there. I was as barren as the smoking ruins on which I stood. I was alone and frightened, and I realised this terrible thing. I realised that it just didn’t matter to me anymore. And there on that sad morning I knew that I would never write again. My soul was empty.

Your soul isn’t empty Father. Your soul has the whole world in it. But even if it was, I’m glad. For it’s brought you home. Will is very moved. 116 INT. JUDITH’S BED CHAMBER - NIGHT 116 Judith in her room. Will appears.
I’m sorry.
You lost your son. Any man would mourn. A daughter is nothing. Destined only to become the property of another man. Or fade away.  All Is True - Shooting Script 56.
You mustn’t fade Judith. Why don’t you write again?
Father you know I can not write.
I could teach you. For a moment Judith is taken aback. This is such a potent resetting of their relationship. But it is too late.
I have no verse in me any more.
Why?
Because the wrong twin died.
No. Plague took him. Plague makes no judgements. It is just plague.
I wish a plague had taken me.
Judith. Why do you hate yourself?
I have stolen Hamnet from you twice. Once by surviving him, and now by taking your dream of him away.
You have given me a new dream. My beautiful daughter, the Poet.
A woman can not be a poet. A woman is put upon this Earth for but one reason. I know my duty now. I will make amends for stealing Hamnet from you. I promise I will make amends.
Will digs. Anne joins him. Beat.
I am glad Hamnet didn’t write the poems.  118 119 120 Anne looks at the garden. It is still pretty grim. smiles. All Is True - Shooting Script
